revised_title: Fossil Shell Distribution and the Extinction of Carnivorous Mollusks
tldr: The author examines the distribution of fossil shells, particularly those of carnivorous mollusks, and observes a rarity in older strata. They propose that the extinction of one predaceous tribe was compensated by the creation of new genera and species with similar appetencies. The author also notes a curious coincidence that marine Trachelipodes of transition and secondary strata are mostly genera with opercula, while unoperculated genera are found in tertiary formations where Ammonites disappear.
